case_vignette: A newborn fullterm female is noted to have a patch of hair loss, prominent leg veins, and shortened fingers at birth. Prenatal course was unremarkable. Physical examination reveals an extensive large ulcerated atrophic plaque on the scalp with surrounding peripheral hair, brachydactyly of index fingers, and lacy reticulated violaceous patches on the right thigh and calf. multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I have a patch of hair loss on my scalp, prominent leg veins, and my index fingers are shorter than usual.
How long have you noticed these symptoms?
I have had these symptoms since birth.
Do you have any other associated symptoms like hearing loss or vision problems?
No, I don't have any hearing loss or vision problems.
Do you have any family members with similar symptoms?
No, none of my family members have similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Turner Syndrome

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a large sore and thin area on my scalp with some hair missing around it, short index fingers, and some purple lace-like patches on my right thigh and calf.
Have you experienced any recent unexplained weight loss or night sweats?
No, I have not experienced any unexplained weight loss or night sweats.

No, I do not have any history of kidney issues, and there is no family history of kidney diseases mentioned.

No, there are no known genetic disorders or a history of genetic disorders in my family.
Has there been any change in the appearance or size of the sore on your scalp over time?
Yes, the sore on my scalp is extensive and has an ulcerated atrophic plaque.
Final Diagnosis: Lichen Planopilaris.
